captions.text: If you see how things are in reality, these are things that you simply...
...cannot imagine from your office, how things once were.
Of course I still have faith; it’s going to be very exciting.
In this series of films we take you on a journey through the development...
...and creation of Efteling’s latest spectacular attraction.
In this episode we join the design team on a visit to actual mining operations.
And see how traditional craftsmanship is used in the building work.
Where does the inspiration for the design come from?
And is the project still running to schedule?
This is 'The Making of: Baron 1898'
To gain inspiration both during the design phase and in the project’s realisation...
...part of the creative team is visiting a real mine.
This is a useful way in which to incorporate authentic details in the design of the new attraction.
Today we are in Zollverein, in Germany.
We’re here to take a look at typical mine architecture both inside and outside this enormous mining operation.
It’s incredibly beautiful to see how things really were.
The brickwork, the structure, the whole atmosphere of the place and the paving.
It’s a real source of inspiration for us to draw upon.
We also visited the Netherlands Mining Museum in Heerlen.
Where we were shown around by a group of former mineworkers.
They provided us with a detailed insight into daily working life.
We have learnt what a mineworker’s average day would have been like back then.
What went on in the morning and afternoon shifts and how things looked at the end of a shift.
We will try to use the information we have gained in the storytelling...
...and scenes that will later appear in the attraction.
We were very impressed with the original mining equipment, which was needed to tunnel underground.
We were very impressed with the original mining equipment, which was needed to tunnel underground.
We want to bring that sense of adventure to Efteling.
Items of equipment like these are essential to bringing our story, the legend of the mine, to life at Efteling.
That’s why we’re on the lookout for mining equipment.
These are the kind of original components we need for our attraction.
They add meaning and authenticity, making it seem like we’re opening an actual mine.
The nice thing about this particular architectural period, 1898, is the attention to detail.
The attention paid to the finishing of the window frames.
And to the brickwork surrounding them, the choice of bricks used and the paving work.
There’s a romantic feel to many of these aspects.
That’s the nice thing about visiting an actual mining operation and seeing how it appears in reality.
These are things that you simply cannot imagine from your office.
You have to see and experience how things once were in real life to make the right choices for our visitors.
The style we have chosen is very much informed by what we saw in Zollverein.
Lots of brickwork detailing, nooks, many edges and the pointing is quite rough.
The bricks don’t all have to be perfectly flat.
The wall should look like it has stood there for a hundred years and has been through a lot in that time.
So a few of the bricks are broken.
The bricklayers have to do this on site and this is something they’re not used to or happy about being asked.
But if you look at them now, they’re singing and whistling while they work.
Outside the terminal building we are currently busy creating the attraction’s foundations.
Each foundation must support one of the rollercoaster’s columns.
The tunnel entrance trough will be completely excavated and filled with water, to prevent it from rising to the surface.
Once that’s completed, we will continue with the casting of underwater concrete with the help of divers.
The weather has been very favourable up to now. It’s been a little cold and we have had some rain but we’ve been able to work through it.
We are also making preparations to see what measures we can take if the weather deteriorates.
Of course I still have faith; it’s going to be very exciting.
Work on the terminal building is focused on completing the basic shell before the first heavy frosts arrive.
In addition, the Decoration and Design department is taking the first steps towards introducing some of the building’s unique decorative elements.
Baron 1898 is beginning to take shape…
Subscribe and stay on the lookout for further episodes of 'The Making-of: Baron 1898'.
